advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote>... featuring the Intellivoice</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - FEB.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Quite impressive, non ?!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/"><img src="http://www.page.sannet.ne.jp/sasajima/pc/cata/ban_pc1s.gif" border="0"></a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>These in an advert from 84, for 3 models of Hectors (Hector 16k, Hector 2HR+ 48k & Hector HRX 64k).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #1 JAN. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (OCTOBER 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil plays on all tables"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAIL ORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Computer assisted mail-order <br><br> As soon as the home computers could communicate easily through modem with large computer sites, the major mail-order companies had the idea to sell products to the computers users. This concept was facilitated in France by the free distribution of the 'Minitel' Videotex terminal that was gradually integrated into home computers. The success gained by this system in France did not have any equal in the rest of the world. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (SEPT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The incredible Secam color micro-computer !"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">PC Leaflets Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (FEB. 1980) </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the first advert for the Atari 520ST checked against an Apple Mac and an Apricot computer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bradley Sturch</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/" target="_blank">Soichiro's Oga</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE TEMPTATION...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Franklin dealer advert (1983)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1946...</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an extract of the promotional guide. It says: <br><br> <font color="#666666">1946... Today the TO 7<br> 1946: 30 tons, 160 m²<br> Today: 3.5 Kg, 0.01 m²</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Personal Computer MZ-811 is a class of itself. Its infinite applications mark it." <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This is a Famicom compatible handheld system. It is the ultimate handheld system for all Famicom fans!
The Game Axe is a complete hand-held system with volume & brightness knobs, two controller connectors and even Audio/Video IN and OUT ports! Thus it is possible to use the Game Axe on a TV (NTSC) like a "normal" console. You can then turn off the LCD screen thanks to a LCD toggle switch. With the A/V IN port you can connect any video source to watch on the LCD screen. Just imagine how useful this can be! The only thing the Game Axe lacks when compared to a Famicom, is the the expansion port.
You can play almost every games produced for the Famicom (some unlicenced ones won't work). American and European NES game can be played by using a special 60-72 pin converter.
There were in fact two versions of the Game Axe, the FC-812 and the FC-868 (Super Game Axe). The FC-812 was produced from 1995 until 1997, it had a 3" (7.26cm) screen, ared power led and a characteristic white border around it. The FC-868 was produced from 1997 until present. It has a 4"(10.2cm) screen and a green power LED. This is the most common version found nowadays.
computer.graphics: 160 x 192 with 16 colors, 64 sprites (8 x 8 pixels, or 8 x 16)
computer.keyboard: 8-directions standard digital joypad. 4 buttons (A, B, Turbo A, Turbo B). START, SELECT
computer.name: Game Axe
computer.ports: DC in, Famicom Cartridge slot, A/V Out (NTSC), A/V In, 2 x controller connectors, phone
computer.power: 6 AA batteries, or 9 volts DC, center-negative polarity, between 500-1000mA

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>This FC-812 model was the first Game Axe produced. The 3” screen (smaller than the 4" screen of the second version) has a characteristic white border around it and the power LED is red.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.lik-sang.com" target="_blank">www.lik-sang.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.lik-sang.com" target="_blank">www.lik-sang.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.lik-sang.com" target="_blank">www.lik-sang.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.lik-sang.com" target="_blank">www.lik-sang.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.sound: pAPU (pseudo-Audio Processing Unit), 4 analog channels, 1 digital channel
